title: Learn HTML
description: Master HTML from basics to advanced with examples and projects. The essential starting point for any web developer.

lessons.title: What is HTML?
lessons.content:
What is HTML?

HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language. It is the standard markup language for creating Web pages.

  • HTML describes the structure of a Web page.
  • HTML consists of a series of elements.
  • HTML elements tell the browser how to display the content.
  • HTML elements label pieces of content such as "this is a heading", "this is a paragraph", "this is a link", etc.
lessons.exampleCode:
My First Heading

My first paragraph.

lessons.title: HTML Document Structure
lessons.content:
A Simple HTML Document

All HTML documents must start with a document type declaration: <!DOCTYPE html>.

The HTML document itself begins with <html> and ends with </html>.

The visible part of the HTML document is between <body> and </body>.

Example:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <title>Page Title</title>
</head>
<body>

  <h1>My First Heading</h1>
  <p>My first paragraph.</p>

</body>
</html>

The <head> element contains meta-information about the document, like its title, character set, styles, links, scripts, and other meta information.

lessons.title: Headings
lessons.content:
HTML Headings

HTML headings are defined with the <h1> to <h6> tags.

<h1> defines the most important heading. <h6> defines the least important heading.

lessons.title: Paragraphs
lessons.content:
HTML Paragraphs

HTML paragraphs are defined with the <p> tag.
lessons.exampleCode:
This is a paragraph.

\n

This is another paragraph.

lessons.title: Links
lessons.content:
HTML Links (Anchors)

HTML links are defined with the <a> tag. The link's destination is specified in the href attribute.

lessons.title: Images
lessons.content:
HTML Images

HTML images are defined with the <img> tag. The source file (src) and alternative text (alt) are provided as attributes.

The `alt` attribute is crucial for accessibility.

lessons.title: Unordered Lists
lessons.content:
Unordered HTML List

An unordered list starts with the <ul> tag. Each list item starts with the <li> tag.

The list items will be marked with bullets (small black circles) by default.

lessons.title: Ordered Lists
lessons.content:
Ordered HTML List

An ordered list starts with the <ol> tag. Each list item starts with the <li> tag.

The list items will be marked with numbers by default.

lessons.title: The Form Element
lessons.content:
The <form> Element

The HTML <form> element is used to create an HTML form for user input. It can contain one or more form elements like text fields, checkboxes, radio buttons, submit buttons, and more.

lessons.title: Input Types
lessons.content:
HTML Input Types

HTML offers many input types for forms. Some of the most common are:

  • <input type="text"> - A single-line text field.
  • <input type="password"> - A password field.
  • <input type="submit"> - A submit button.
  • <input type="radio"> - A radio button.
  • <input type="checkbox"> - A checkbox.

title: Learn CSS
description: Style your websites and bring your designs to life with modern CSS, from basic selectors to advanced layouts.

lessons.title: What is CSS?
lessons.content:
What is CSS?

CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets. It is the language we use to style an HTML document.

CSS describes how HTML elements should be displayed.

  • CSS saves a lot of work. It can control the layout of multiple web pages all at once.
  • External stylesheets are stored in CSS files.

lessons.title: CSS Syntax
lessons.content:
CSS Syntax

A CSS rule-set consists of a selector and a declaration block.

The selector points to the HTML element you want to style.

The declaration block contains one or more declarations separated by semicolons. Each declaration includes a CSS property name and a value, separated by a colon.

lessons.title: Selectors
lessons.content:
CSS Selectors

CSS selectors are used to "find" (or select) the HTML elements you want to style.

Some common selectors include:

  • Element Selector: Selects elements based on the element name (e.g., p).
  • ID Selector: Uses the id attribute of an HTML element to select a specific element (e.g., #firstname). An ID should be unique within a page.
  • Class Selector: Selects elements with a specific class attribute (e.g., .intro).

lessons.title: Colors
lessons.content:
CSS Colors

Colors in CSS can be specified in several ways:

  • By name: red, blue, lightgray
  • By HEX value: #ff0000, #0000ff
  • By RGB value: rgb(255, 0, 0)
